metadata.title: A Statistical Recurrent Model on the Manifold of Symmetric Positive Definite Matrices
metadata.author: Rudrasis Chakraborty, Chun-Hao Yang, Xingjian Zhen, Monami Banerjee, Derek Archer, David Vaillancourt, Vikas Singh, Baba Vemuri
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: In a number of disciplines, the data (e.g., graphs, manifolds) to be analyzed are non-Euclidean in nature. Geometric deep learning corresponds to techniques that generalize deep neural network models to such non-Euclidean spaces. Several recent papers have shown how convolutional neural networks (CNNs) can be extended to learn with graph-based data. In this work, we study the setting where the data (or measurements) are ordered, longitudinal or temporal in nature and live on a Riemannian manifold – this setting is common in a variety of problems in statistical machine learning, vision and medical imaging. We show how recurrent statistical recurrent network models can be defined in such spaces. We give an efficient algorithm and conduct a rigorous analysis of its statistical properties. We perform extensive numerical experiments demonstrating competitive performance with state of the art methods but with significantly less number of parameters. We also show applications to a statistical analysis task in brain imaging, a regime where deep neural network models have only been utilized in limited ways.

highlights: In the last decade or so, deep neural network models have been enormously successful in learning complicated patterns from data such as images, videos and speech [39, 37] – this has led to a number of technological breakthroughs as well as deployments in turnkey applications

We like to point out that though the number of trainable parameters are fewer for SPD-Statistical Recurrent Unit than TT-Recurrent Neural Network, the time difference is due to constructing the covariance in each epoch which can be optimized via faster implementations
Non-Euclidean or manifold valued data are ubiquitous in science and engineering
We study the setting where the data are ordered, longitudinal or temporal in nature and live on a Riemannian manifold
This setting is common in a variety of problems in statistical machine learning, vision and medical imaging
We presented a generalization of the Recurrent Neural Network to such non-Euclidean spaces and analyze its theoretical properties

One of the popular neural network architectures that has contributed to these advancements is convolutional neural networks (CNNs)

We chose different parameters for Statistical Recurrent Unit and Long short term memory and TT-Recurrent Neural Network and the one we reported here are the one for which the number of parameters are smallest for the reported testing accuracy

summary: In the last decade or so, deep neural network models have been enormously successful in learning complicated patterns from data such as images, videos and speech [39, 37] – this has led to a number of technological breakthroughs as well as deployments in turnkey applications.
Important properties of SPD-SRU model: The “translation” operator T is analogous to “adding” a bias term in a standard neural network.

We demonstrate the application of SPD-SRU to answer three important questions (1) Using the manifold constraint, what are we saving in terms of number of parameters/ time and is the performance competitive?

We perform two sets of experiments namely (1) classification of moving patterns on Moving MNIST data, (2) classification of actions on UCF11 data to show the improvement of our proposed framework over the state-of-the-art methods in terms of number of parameters/ time.
One can see from the table that, SPD-SRU takes the least number 1.2 of parameters and can achieve very good classification accuracy even for 5◦ orientation difference and for three classes.

In terms of training time, SPD-SRU takes around Figure 2: Comparison of testing ac6 seconds per epoch while the fastest method is TT-RNN which curacies with varying orientations takes around 2 seconds.

We like to point out that though the number of trainable parameters are fewer for SPD-SRU than TT-RNN, the time difference is due to constructing the covariance in each epoch which can be optimized via faster implementations.
For both SRU and LSTM we used 3 convolution layers with kernel size 7 × 7 and output channels to be 10, 15 and 25 respectively to get the reported testing accuracies.
We can see that the number of parameters for SPD-SRU is significantly smaller than the other models without sacrificing the testing accuracy.
Analogous to the previous experiment, we can conclude that SPD-SRU maintains very good classification accuracy while keeping the number of trainable parameters very small.
This experiment indicates that SPD-SRU can achieve competitive performance on real data with small number of training parameters in comparable time.

For each of these two classes, we use 3 layers of SPD-SRU to learn the tracts pattern to get two models for ‘PD’ and ‘CON’.
We apply our framework to perform statistical analysis in brain connectivity and demonstrate the applicability to manifold valued data
